newsitem.title: GERMANY: Bonn could transfer Postbank, other holdings in 97.
newsitem.headline: Bonn could transfer Postbank, other holdings in 97.

text.p: German government coalition sources said on Wednesday that shares in Postbank AG could be parked with the credit institute Kreditanstalt fuer Wiederaufbau (KfW) this year, and not listed on the stock exchange.
Gert Vogt, chairman of the credit institute that was set up during the Marshall Plan era, said separately that the KfW could take over a considerable volume of state holdings this year.

Bonn coalition sources said transferring the Postbank shares to KfW instead of listing them on the stock exchange in 1997 as previously planned would ensure that funds from the privatisation flowed into the budget this year.
The move is not entirely unexpected following a similar deal last year when the government quickly sold off additional shares in airline Lufthansa AG, placing the shares with KfW.

The Postbank sale, estimated to be worth some three billion marks, is just one of the privatisations that Finance Minister Theo Waigel has decided to bring forward in order create revenue to plug yawning budget deficits and help Germany qualify for European economic and monetary union (EMU).

The finance ministry and the post and telecommunications ministry declined to confirm the plans, saying only that the method by which the Postbank privatisation would be carried out was still under consideration.
KfW chairman Vogt told Reuters the bank was prepared to take over Postbank and other government holdings this year.
He said that considering KfW's balance sheet total of 250 billion marks "this is not a problem to take over holdings with a volume of around 25 billion marks."
